Title.evidence: Plasma Biomarker Kinetics in Identifying Postoperative Pulmonary Complications: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Two hundred and forty-two adult patients scheduled for abdominal surgery and at risk of PPCs were randomised

Participants.evidence: This preplanned substudy of the PROVHILO trial was conducted in the operating rooms of five centers. Two hundred and forty-two adult patients scheduled for abdominal surgery and at risk of PPCs

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either high (12 cmH2O) or low (≤2 cmH2O) PEEP

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates whether plasma biomarker kinetics can identify patients at risk of PPCs and if these kinetics are influenced by intraoperative positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) levels.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was a composite of individual PPCs.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 242 patients were randomised: 120 to high PEEP and 122 to low PEEP.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on all patients using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Increases in TNF-α, IL-6, IL-8, and CC-16, and a decrease in SP-D were more pronounced in patients developing PPCs, but the area under the curve was low for all biomarkers.
